content: The Act may be cited as the "Veterans Health Care Facilities Capital Improvement Act of 2011" and includes a table of contents. The "Veterans Health Care Facilities Capital Improvement Act of 2011" authorizes fiscal year 2012 major medical facility projects, leases, and appropriations. It also modifies requirements for congressional approval of medical facility acquisitions and limits the use of bid savings on construction projects. Additionally, it includes the naming of a telehealth clinic in Craig, Colorado, and the George H. O'Brien, Jr., Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center. Authorization of appropriations for comprehensive service programs for homeless veterans, reauthorization of financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing, extension of grant program for homeless veterans with special needs, extension of specially adapted housing assistance, extension of funding fees, notice and verification of income information use from other agencies, termination or reduction of benefits based on income information obtained from other agencies. Authorization of fiscal year 2012 major medical facility projects by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. In fiscal year 2012, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out major medical facility projects including seismic corrections for Building 100 in Seattle, Washington ($51.8 million) and renovations for housing facilities for homeless veterans in West Los Angeles, California ($35.5 million). Additionally, there is a modification of authorization for certain major medical facility construction projects previously authorized. The Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Fayetteville, Arkansas is amending a project to include a parking garage and increase the budget from $56,163,000 to $90,600,000. In Orlando, Florida, a major medical facility construction project is being extended to include a Simulation, Learning, Education, and Research Network Center. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may increase the authorization amount for the major medical facility project in Palo Alto, California to $716,600,000. Additionally, the authorization amount for the major medical facility project in San Juan, Puerto Rico may be increased. The Health and Other Care Improvements Act of 2008 is amended to increase funding from $225,900,000 to $277,000,000. The authorization amount for the fiscal year 2007 major medical facility project in St. Louis, Missouri is increased from $69,053,000 to $346,300,000. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to carry out fiscal year 2012 major medical facility leases in Columbus, Georgia and Fort Wayne, Indiana. Authorization of appropriations for construction in various outpatient clinics across different states, with specific amounts allocated for each location. Total funding to be appropriated to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for fiscal year 2012. In fiscal year 2012, funds are authorized for construction projects in the Construction, Major Projects, and Medical Facilities accounts. $87,300,000 is allocated for projects in section 2, $850,070,000 for projects in section 3, and $49,292,000 for leases in section 4. These projects must be carried out using the authorized appropriations. Funds for construction projects in fiscal year 2012 can be used from various sources including appropriations from previous years and funds not specific to a project. SEC. 6. Modification of requirements for congressional approval of medical facility acquisitions under title 38, United States Code, includes amending subsection (b) to provide a detailed estimate of total costs for construction projects, including construction costs, activation costs, special purpose alterations costs, and personnel numbers. The Secretary must obtain congressional approval before expanding the purpose of a major construction project. SEC. 8. The Department of Veterans Affairs telehealth clinic in Craig, Colorado, will be renamed as the "Major William Edward Adams Department of Veterans Affairs Clinic". Any references to the clinic will now be to the new name. SEC. 9. The George H. O'Brien, Jr., Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center will be designated as such. The Department of Veterans Affairs medical center in Big Spring, Texas will be renamed as the "George H. O'Brien, Jr., Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center". References to the center in any official documents will now reflect the new name. Additionally, certain expiring authorities related to recovery audits for contracts and homeless veterans reintegration programs have been extended to September 30, 2020 and 2012 respectively. The sections in the title related to treatment, rehabilitation, additional services, housing assistance, and advisory committee for homeless veterans have been amended to extend the deadlines from December 31, 2011, to December 31, 2012. SEC. 11 amends Section 2013 of title 38, United States Code, to authorize appropriations for comprehensive service programs for homeless veterans for fiscal years 2007 through 2013 and subsequent years. SEC. 12 reauthorizes appropriations for financial assistance. SEC. 12 reauthorizes appropriations for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing, allocating $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2012. SEC. 13 extends the grant program for homeless veterans with special needs to fiscal year 2012. SEC. 14 extends specially adapted housing assistance. SEC. 14 extends specially adapted housing assistance by amending Section 2102A(e) of title 38, United States Code to change the date from "2011" to "2012". Section 453(j)(11)(G) of the Social Security Act is amended to change the date from "September 30, 2011" to "November 18, 2011".
